#Text=Philip J.
#Text=Wyatt
#Text=Philip
#Text=J.
#Text=Wyatt
#Text=is the founder and CEO of Wyatt Technology , located in Santa Barbara , California .

#Text=He is known for contributions to laser light scattering , more specifically the physics of the inverse scattering problem and for commercializing analytical methods and instruments involving laser light scattering , which are widely used in academia , industry , and government .
#Text=Early life and education
#Text=Wyatt did undergraduate work at the University of Chicago , ( B.A. , 1952 ; B. Sc . , 1954 ) , and Christ 's College , Cambridge .
#Text=He received his M.S. from the University of Illinois in 1956 [ 1 ] and his Ph.D. from Florida State University in 1959 , where he first worked on the inverse scattering problem .
#Text=His Ph.D. work involved the development of a non‑local nuclear model of the scattering of neutrons by nuclei . [ 1 ]
#Text=He was nominated by the National Academy of Sciences in 1965 as one of sixteen possible candidates for the first Scientist-Astronaut Selection Program in the United States . [ 2 ] [ 3 ]
#Text=Career
#Text=As a graduate student , Wyatt worked at Los Alamos National Laboratory .
#Text=During the 1960s , he worked for the Aeronutronic division of Ford Motor Company , General Research Corporation in Santa Barbara , California , and the defense contractor EG&G . [ 2 ]
#Text=Wyatt founded his first company , Science Spectrum , Inc. , in 1968 .
#Text=The company developed several instruments that could be used to study the inverse scattering problem .
#Text=They applied light-scattering techniques to the detection of biological weapons and the monitoring of food quality .
#Text=These early instruments used a traditional single detector to scan a range of scattering angles .

#Text=Shortly before the closure of the company in 1982 , Wyatt developed an instrument for multi-angle light scattering ( MALS ) in which a glass capillary containing a sample was surrounded by an array of detectors . [ 4 ]
#Text=Wyatt then founded Wyatt Technology Corporation to develop and sell laser‑based scientific instruments for light scattering and particle size measurement .
#Text=His instruments are used worldwide by universities , government agencies , the biotech industry and pharmaceutical companies . [ 1 ] [ 5 ]
#Text=Wyatt 's instruments are used in a wide variety of fields .
#Text=Laser particle analysis has been applied to wine and to cleaning products . [ 4 ] [ 5 ]
#Text=The U.S. Government has supported work on the identification of bioterrorism threats such as airborne bacteria [ 1 ] and metabolic poisons or carcinogens in drinking water . [ 4 ]
#Text=Wyatt 's instruments are used for protein analysis by biopharmaceutical companies such as Amgen . [ 5 ]
#Text=They are used for detection of drug and pesticide residues in meat , and monitoring for possible toxicity of AZT and antineoplastic drugs in patients . [ 1 ]
#Text=Nobel prize winner Robert H. Grubbs uses them to study polymers . [ 5 ]
#Text=They are also used to monitor smog and fly ash , and identify effective antibiotics to counter bacterial infections . [ 1 ]
#Text=“ Get into a market that is just on the verge of developing .
#Text=If you ’re too early , the company fails .
#Text=If you ’re a little too late , the competitors will eat you alive because they have much better resources . ”
#Text=Philip J. Wyatt [ 1 ]
#Text=Wyatt has published over seventy publications , including books .
#Text=He has at least ninety domestic and foreign patents related to laser light scattering and other technologies . [ 6 ]
#Text=Wyatt served as the 2012-2013
#Text=Chair of the American Physical Society 's Forum on Industrial and Applied Physics . [ 1 ]
#Text=He is the 2016-2017 Vice Chair of the American Physical Society ’s Group on Instrument and Measurement Science , from which he will succeed to the position of chair . [ 7 ]
#Text=Wyatt also serves on the board of directors of the Santa Barbara City College . [ 3 ]
#Text=Awards and honors

#Text=2009 , Inaugural Prize for Industrial Applications of Physics from the American Physical Society “ for pioneering developments in the physics of the inverse scattering problem : new application of laser light scattering and the successful sustained commercialization of new related analytical methods and instrumentation . ” [ 1 ] [ 8 ]
#Text=2003 , " Graduate of Distinction " , College of Arts and Sciences , Florida State University . [ 2 ]
